name: Washington
predecessorContext: First president - no predecessor
successorContext: Established precedents followed by John Adams and all future presidents
majorEvents: Revolutionary War hero, Constitutional Convention, established executive branch precedents
anchorNote: The founding anchor - everyone knows #1

name: J. Adams
predecessorContext: Washington's Vice President for 8 years, first peaceful transfer of power
successorContext: Lost to Jefferson in bitter 1800 election, father of John Quincy Adams (#6)
majorEvents: XYZ Affair, Alien and Sedition Acts, avoided war with France
anchorNote: First VP to become President, father-son presidential pair

name: Jefferson
predecessorContext: Adams' VP, defeated Adams in 1800 'Revolution of 1800'
successorContext: Followed by his Secretary of State Madison, starting 'Virginia Dynasty'
majorEvents: Louisiana Purchase doubled nation's size, Lewis and Clark expedition
anchorNote: Author of Declaration of Independence, faces on nickel and $2 bill

name: Madison
predecessorContext: Jefferson's Secretary of State, continued Virginia Dynasty
successorContext: Followed by Monroe, his Secretary of State - Virginia Dynasty continues
majorEvents: War of 1812, British burned White House, 'Father of the Constitution'
anchorNote: Shortest president (5'4"), wrote much of Constitution and Bill of Rights

name: Monroe
predecessorContext: Madison's Secretary of State, last of Virginia Dynasty founders
successorContext: Followed by J.Q. Adams in contested 1824 election decided by House
majorEvents: Monroe Doctrine, Era of Good Feelings, Missouri Compromise
anchorNote: Last Founding Father president, last to wear Revolutionary-era clothing

name: J.Q. Adams
predecessorContext: Son of John Adams (#2), won disputed 1824 election via House vote
successorContext: Lost rematch to Jackson in 1828, later served in House of Representatives
majorEvents: Corrupt Bargain controversy, internal improvements, later anti-slavery advocate
anchorNote: Only president who was son of a president (until Bush 43)

name: Jackson
predecessorContext: Lost 1824 despite popular vote, defeated J.Q. Adams in 1828 rematch
successorContext: Followed by his VP Van Buren, Jackson's hand-picked successor
majorEvents: Indian Removal Act, killed National Bank, first 'common man' president
anchorNote: Old Hickory, War of 1812 hero, face on $20 bill

name: Van Buren
predecessorContext: Jackson's VP and chosen successor, first president born US citizen
successorContext: Lost to W.H. Harrison in 1840 'log cabin' campaign
majorEvents: Panic of 1837, Trail of Tears continued, independent treasury
anchorNote: First president born American citizen, 'OK' may come from 'Old Kinderhook'

name: W.H. Harrison
predecessorContext: Defeated Van Buren, oldest president elected until Reagan
successorContext: Died 31 days in, succeeded by Tyler in first presidential death
majorEvents: Longest inaugural address, caught pneumonia, shortest presidency
anchorNote: Tippecanoe and Tyler Too, grandfather of Benjamin Harrison (#23)

name: Tyler
predecessorContext: First VP to succeed due to death, 'His Accidency'
successorContext: Not nominated by either party, succeeded by Polk
majorEvents: Established precedent that VP becomes full president, Texas annexation started
anchorNote: First accidental president, expelled from Whig party while president

name: Polk
predecessorContext: Dark horse candidate, defeated Henry Clay
successorContext: Kept promise to serve one term, died 3 months after leaving office
majorEvents: Mexican-American War, acquired California and Southwest, Oregon Treaty
anchorNote: Achieved all 4 major goals, most successful one-term president

name: Taylor
predecessorContext: Mexican-American War hero, never voted before elected
successorContext: Died 16 months in, succeeded by Fillmore during slavery crisis
majorEvents: Compromise of 1850 debates, died possibly from gastroenteritis
anchorNote: Old Rough and Ready, second president to die in office

name: Fillmore
predecessorContext: Taylor's VP, took office during Compromise of 1850 crisis
successorContext: Not nominated in 1852, later ran on Know-Nothing ticket
majorEvents: Signed Compromise of 1850 including Fugitive Slave Act
anchorNote: Last Whig president, opened trade with Japan

name: Pierce
predecessorContext: Dark horse, son died in train accident before inauguration
successorContext: Not renominated, followed by Buchanan as tensions rise toward Civil War
majorEvents: Kansas-Nebraska Act led to Bleeding Kansas, accelerated path to Civil War
anchorNote: Only elected president not nominated for second term by his party

name: Buchanan
predecessorContext: Followed Pierce as sectional crisis deepened
successorContext: Inaction on secession left Lincoln facing Civil War
majorEvents: Dred Scott decision, did nothing as states seceded, widely considered worst president
anchorNote: Only president from Pennsylvania, only bachelor president

name: Lincoln
predecessorContext: Elected as nation fell apart, Buchanan left him secession crisis
successorContext: Assassinated, succeeded by Johnson who clashed with Congress on Reconstruction
majorEvents: Civil War, Emancipation Proclamation, preserved the Union, Gettysburg Address
anchorNote: MAJOR ANCHOR: #16, face on penny and $5, greatest president debate

name: Johnson
predecessorContext: Lincoln's VP from unity ticket, became president after assassination
successorContext: Impeached, barely acquitted, followed by Grant
majorEvents: Reconstruction battles with Congress, first president impeached, Alaska Purchase
anchorNote: Only Southern senator to stay loyal to Union, tailor by trade

name: Grant
predecessorContext: Civil War hero, elected to heal nation after Johnson's failures
successorContext: Followed by Hayes in disputed 1876 election ending Reconstruction
majorEvents: Reconstruction enforcement, 15th Amendment, scandals but personally honest
anchorNote: Union general who won Civil War, face on $50 bill

name: Hayes
predecessorContext: Won disputed 1876 election, ended Reconstruction in compromise
successorContext: Kept one-term pledge, followed by Garfield (another Ohio Republican)
majorEvents: Compromise of 1877 ended Reconstruction, civil service reform started
anchorNote: Rutherfraud - disputed election decided by commission

name: Garfield
predecessorContext: Dark horse nominee, continued Ohio Republican streak
successorContext: Assassinated 6 months in, succeeded by Arthur
majorEvents: Shot by disappointed office seeker, died from doctors' infections
anchorNote: Last log cabin president, assassination led to civil service reform

name: Arthur
predecessorContext: Garfield's VP, became president after assassination
successorContext: Not nominated in 1884, followed by Cleveland (Democrat)
majorEvents: Pendleton Civil Service Act reformed spoils system, surprised reformers
anchorNote: Former spoils system politician who championed civil service reform

name: Cleveland
predecessorContext: First Democrat since Civil War, defeated Blaine
successorContext: Lost to B. Harrison in 1888 despite popular vote, would return as #24
majorEvents: First term: vetoed pension frauds, Interstate Commerce Act
anchorNote: Only president to serve non-consecutive terms (#22 AND #24)

name: B. Harrison
predecessorContext: Grandson of W.H. Harrison (#9), won electoral college despite losing popular vote
successorContext: Lost 1892 rematch to Cleveland, who became #24
majorEvents: McKinley Tariff, Sherman Antitrust Act, six states admitted
anchorNote: Grandson of #9, sandwiched between Cleveland's two terms

name: Cleveland
predecessorContext: Won rematch against B. Harrison, only non-consecutive president
successorContext: Followed by McKinley as economy and foreign policy shifted
majorEvents: Second term: Panic of 1893, Pullman Strike, secret cancer surgery
anchorNote: Same person as #22 - only non-consecutive terms president

name: McKinley
predecessorContext: Defeated Bryan in 1896, ended Gilded Age economic debates
successorContext: Assassinated in 1901, succeeded by young reformer T. Roosevelt
majorEvents: Spanish-American War, Philippines acquired, Gold Standard Act
anchorNote: Last Civil War veteran president, assassination elevated TR

name: T. Roosevelt
predecessorContext: McKinley's VP, became youngest president at 42 after assassination
successorContext: Hand-picked Taft as successor, later ran against him in 1912
majorEvents: Trust-busting, Panama Canal, national parks, Nobel Peace Prize
anchorNote: On Mount Rushmore, youngest president ever, 'Speak softly and carry a big stick'

name: Taft
predecessorContext: TR's chosen successor, won easily in 1908
successorContext: Lost to Wilson in 1912 three-way race with TR, later became Chief Justice
majorEvents: More trust-busting than TR, income tax amendment, split with Roosevelt
anchorNote: Only president to also serve as Chief Justice, heaviest president

name: Wilson
predecessorContext: Won due to Taft-TR split, first Southerner since Civil War
successorContext: Stroke incapacitated him, followed by Harding's 'return to normalcy'
majorEvents: WWI, League of Nations (rejected), Federal Reserve, women's suffrage
anchorNote: Led US through WWI, idealistic 14 Points, Nobel Peace Prize

name: Harding
predecessorContext: Promised 'return to normalcy' after Wilson's idealism
successorContext: Died in office 1923, succeeded by Coolidge as scandals emerged
majorEvents: Teapot Dome scandal discovered after death, died of heart attack
anchorNote: Often ranked worst president, scandals discovered posthumously

name: Coolidge
predecessorContext: Harding's VP, became president when Harding died
successorContext: Chose not to run in 1928, followed by Hoover just before Depression
majorEvents: Roaring Twenties prosperity, 'Silent Cal', small government philosophy
anchorNote: Sworn in by his father (a notary) at 2:47 AM by kerosene lamp

name: Hoover
predecessorContext: Commerce Secretary, elected in 1928 prosperity
successorContext: Blamed for Depression, crushed by FDR in 1932
majorEvents: Great Depression began 1929, Hoovervilles, seen as ineffective
anchorNote: Great humanitarian before presidency, unfairly blamed for Depression

name: FDR
predecessorContext: Defeated Hoover in 1932 landslide during Great Depression
successorContext: Died in office 1945, succeeded by VP Truman
majorEvents: New Deal, Social Security, WWII, only president elected 4 times
anchorNote: Longest-serving president, led through Depression and WWII, polio
